{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's symptoms of perioral numbness, muscle cramping, and hand spasm (Trousseau sign) are suggestive of hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia can occur after thyroidectomy due to inadvertent removal or damage to the parathyroid glands, which are located near the thyroid gland. The elevated parathyroid hormone level indicates that the parathyroid glands are functioning and responding appropriately to the low calcium level. The most likely cause of hypocalcemia in this patient is inadequate calcium intake or absorption. The patient's recent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery could have led to decreased calcium absorption because the duodenum and proximal jejunum, the primary sites of calcium absorption, are bypassed.
